name: Reykjavik
fun_fact: Fun fact: Anthony Bourdain called fermented shark (h치karl) 'the single worst, most disgusting and terrible tasting thing' he'd ever eaten - yet it's been Iceland's national dish for over 1,000 years! Early Icelanders buried toxic shark meat to ferment it, making it edible.

hero_dishes.name: Pylsur (Icelandic Hot Dog)
hero_dishes.description: Sometimes called Iceland's unofficial national dish - unique hot dogs made from blend of lamb, beef, and pork, served 'me칧 칬llu' (with everything): mustard, ketchup, deep-fried onions, creamy remoulade, and crispy raw onions
hero_dishes.origin_story: The Danish brought hot dogs to Iceland in early 20th century, but Iceland had no pig farms. So Icelanders adapted by blending local lamb with beef and pork, creating their own unique version that became a national icon.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: B칝jarins Beztu Pylsur ('The Best in Town') - famous stand visited by Bill Clinton and the Kardashians. Order 'eina me칧 칬llu' for the true Reykjavik experience. Found throughout the city but this stand is legendary.

hero_dishes.name: H치karl (Fermented Shark)
hero_dishes.description: National dish of Iceland - Greenland shark cured through particular fermentation process and hung to dry for 4-5 months. Strong ammonia-rich smell and fishy taste make it an acquired taste.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Born out of Viking-era ingenuity and resourcefulness. Shark eaten fresh is toxic, so early Icelanders developed fermentation by burying the meat, allowing it to ferment, then hanging it to dry - making the toxic edible. Represents survival during harsh winters when nothing would grow.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Readily available in Icelandic stores year-round. Most often served as part of 룚rramatur (traditional food selection at midwinter 룚rrabl칩t festival). Typically served with shot of Brenniv칤n (Iceland's national spirit). Many restaurants offer it as a cultural experience.

hero_dishes.name: Fresh Icelandic Lamb
hero_dishes.description: Free-range Icelandic lamb roasted or slow-cooked, tender and flavorful from sheep that graze on herbs and grasses in pristine landscapes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Lamb has been central to Icelandic survival since Viking settlement. The Icelandic sheep breed is virtually unchanged for over 1,000 years, giving unique flavor.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: New Nordic Cuisine restaurants throughout Reykjavik, showcasing modern techniques with traditional ingredients

hero_dishes.name: Fresh Atlantic Fish
hero_dishes.description: Cod, haddock, Arctic char, and other fish from pristine Icelandic waters, often simply prepared to highlight quality
hero_dishes.origin_story: Iceland's fishing heritage centers cuisine on exceptionally fresh seafood from cold North Atlantic waters
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Restaurants throughout Reykjavik's Old Harbour area, fish markets

hero_dishes.name: Skyr
hero_dishes.description: Traditional Icelandic cultured dairy product similar to thick yogurt but technically a cheese - high protein, low fat, slightly tangy
hero_dishes.origin_story: Brought to Iceland by Vikings over 1,000 years ago, skyr has been a staple of Icelandic diet through harsh winters
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Every grocery store, caf칠s, served at breakfast throughout Iceland with berries and honey

signature_drinks.name: Brenniv칤n
signature_drinks.description: Iceland's signature spirit - unsweetened schnapps made from fermented grain or potato mash, flavored with caraway seeds. Nicknamed 'Black Death'.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Traditionally served ice-cold as a shot alongside fermented shark (h치karl) to cut the strong ammonia taste. Part of 룚rrabl칩t midwinter feast tradition.

signature_drinks.name: Icelandic Craft Beer
signature_drinks.description: Thriving craft beer scene despite beer being banned until 1989
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed in Reykjavik's vibrant pub scene, celebrating Iceland's young but passionate brewing culture
